editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Religious-Rebell, OR THE Pilgrim-Prince. A TRAGAEDY.

list.item: Henry the Fourth Emperour of Germany.

Saxon Nobles
Magnus
Rodolphus
Frederick
Otho.

Nobles of Italie.
Prudentio
Honorio
Junio.

Women.
Sophrona, The Empreſſe.
Aurelia, Her Daughter.
Sylvia, Her Maid of Honour.
Madam Matilda, a great Court Lady:
Ladies.

div.head: Act. 1 Scen. 1.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: MAſs! thou haſt got a luckie hand Brazutus,
The Septicollis now of Rome is levell'd,
My way made even to St. Peters chair,
The Popedome mine!

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: God bleſs your Holineſs!
Never had men quicker diſpatch to Heaven,
(I Judge Sir) that thoſe ſeven your predeceſſors,
Thanks to my luckey ſtarres, and pills! (then which
There can be nothing more Infallible)
(Your Holineſs excepted)

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Your Toe, good Sir, your Toe's too great a honour.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Murder as many as thou canſt, Brazutus,
(Husband it likewiſe to thy beſt advantage,
I know mens Deaths muſt be thy Livelyhood)
You freely have my Diſpenſation for it.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: All thanks, Sir,
My ſtudy ſhall be to deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Harke.
They come, I muſt retire.

div.stage: Enter Cardinal Victor, with a Mitre, other Cardinals, Monks Fryers, with a mixt company.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: God ſave the Pope!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Peter th' Apoſtle chooſeth Hildebrand!

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Maſter! the Kettle-drumms paſt by juſt now.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Peace foole, thoſe were religious men, call'd Fryers.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Men! ſhave they for the ſcabb? or were half poyſon'd?
Pox on the bungler! could his feeble doſſe,
But fetch the hair off?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No Jeſts now, Jocoſo.
Haſten home, I am with you ſtraight; but firſt
Will fetch my Patent, to prepare for travel:
I cannot think it ſafe, abiding here,
So near the Pope, ſhould once his Magick prompt
Him to beleive, ſome liberal bribes might tempt
Me to ridd him hence (by one ſlight or other)
(To make all ſure) he'd ſend me packing firſt.
For all his fair pretenſes I confeſs,
I dare not too much truſt his Holyneſs.

div.head: Act. 1. Scen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Honorio, Prudentio, to them Junio:

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: How can the Emperour take this Prudentio:

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Pride and Ambition ruines all the world.
Truth, Sir, I fear 'twill breed bad bloud, if not
Timely made up; He's a Prince wiſe and valiant,
And wont be baulk'd thus of his ancient right.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Hildebrand reckons all the Roman Empire,
May I not ſay the the whole fourth Monarchie?
For Peter's Patrimony, falling now,
To him, whereof he will be ſole, ſupream;
Making the Scepter level to his Mitre.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Muſt none arrive to heaven without his leave,
Nor yet poſſeſs the earth in any quiet?
Would he be Metropolitane of both?
I muſt confeſs, to men in Sacred Orders,
We owe all love, awful reſpect and honour;
Yet there are two extreams do ill become
Their cloth Honorio, Pride and Poverty:
I'de neither have them ſwell, nor ſtarve to death.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Here comes mad Junio.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: God ſave you, Sir!

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Yours Prudentio, Honorio I am yours!

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Junio, ſweet Junio! prethee lad, what news?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Faith, that which makes me laugh, Sir, The new Pope
(Talking againſt Maſſing-Preiſts Wives already:)
Hath wrought the prettieſt different effect:
Some ſtorme, and ſome are glad on't: The one ſwears
(Should he nere uſe bead more) he'l never quit
His pretty Bet • y for an Ave Marie.
• h' other complains, Nets Lectures ſpoil his Sermons.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Mad Junio ſtill.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Troth, I am ſerious, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Prethee ſpeak

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am, and can tell you further,
Th' Arch-biſhops Grace of Mentz, the other day,
Preſſing this Order, from his Holineſs,
Narrowly ſcap'd his life.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What project's this?
I warrant you Prudentio, Some cunning
Citizen Miſer (to preſerve his purſe)
(Fearing leaſt his Impropriated Preiſt
Might Marry, and ſo leave a pariſh charge)
Hath put it in his head.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: With this perſwaſion.
Moſt Benefic'd men dying Batchelours,
Would make him Heir, and ſo enrich his See.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I had almoſt forgot to tell you too:
Thoſe who contrive the thriftieſt way to live,
Think Wives, will be as cheap as Concubines.
Cardinal Cremenſis the other day,
(Arguing fiercely 'ganſt Prieſts-Matrimonie)
Was catcht that night bedding a common ſtrumpet.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: I fear this deſign will but promote
Luſts more, and ſecret Murders to conceal 'um.
Reſtraint oft creates thoſe unruly paſſions,
Which Freedom, ſlights.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: But Gentlemen! before
We part let's claſh one pint of Wine together,
I'le give you that ſhall be moſt excellent.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: All thanks kind Junio. Ho. We'll accept your proffer.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: With all my heart; now I could hugg you dearly.
Let times go how they will, the Grape-juyce merits
My praiſes ſtill, for that preſerves my ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Poetical!

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Whether or no, you know it:
The very thoughts of Sack will make a Poet.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Ha. ha. ha.

div.head: Act. 1. Scen. 3.
div.stage: Enter Emperour, Henry, Conrade, Attendants. to them Otho.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: It can't be born! Princes are things too holy
For Popes to • oole: Hath kind fate bleſt me with
Such conqueſt o're the Saxons, and will this
Religious Rebel, now ſpoyl all at home?
To make a Pope without me, is all one
As to unmake me.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Sir, I thought that paſt
The reach of mortals, dare they ſnarch that Crown off,
Which none, but a Divine hand ſetled on you?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: They had as good ſeek to unravel Heaven,
And fetch the Diety thence.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: My Sons talk,
As if deſcended, from Imperial Loines;
But what wont human Impudence attempt,
Spurr'd with ambition?
What meanes this haſte?

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Hildebrand's Nuntio, is arriv'd, Sir, And—

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: And what, Sends for my Scepter doth he not?
May I nere more ask pardon of my ſins!
If this ſteel doth not make him cry me mercy.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: And ſo he doth, Sir, may it pleaſe your Highneſs!

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: He ſhall know that there was a Caeſar long
Before St. Peter, or his Succeſſor
Were ever thought on. Otho. May it pleaſe your Highneſs!

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: The Election of the Pope from Conſtantine
Deſcended to Me, Otho, Reckon that.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: 'Tis now Seven Hundred years agon, and upwards.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Nor ſhall this • ome-Uſurper ſtand a day,
Can I but once reach Italie.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Pleaſe you —
Sir, Hear me, Hildebrand is ſorry.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: For that he cannot, Sir, play Preſter John.
Be Prince and Prelate too.

sp.speaker: Emp,
sp.l: Grant he were ſo,
Could it be thought theſe twins of government,
Might ever wrangle in the ſelf-ſame breaſt
For the Supremacy; It would be found,
(I lay my life on't) that St. Peters Chair
Muſt owe it ſelf upheld by Caeſars Throne.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Sir,—

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: No Bull like the roaring Cannon, No
Anathama like a good Sword and Piſtol.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: I ſee I am ſtill diſturb'd.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Go on, Otho.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: For ought we hear, Sir, Hildibrand is ſorry,
The lawleſs rout of common people ſhould
Cry him up Pope: which Title he proteſts
He ne're will own, Sir, without your Election.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I hate this flattering.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: It takes too much.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Till when he hath refus'd Inauguration.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Now thou ſaiſt ſomewhat.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: For this very purpoſe,
Comes th'Embaſſie.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: This is ſome ſatisfaction.
Receive 'um, we will give 'um ſome Audience.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Were it not fit Hildebrand ſhould have made
Moſt Royal, Sir, a Perſonal ſubmiſſion?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Proxy humilitie ſeems but preſumption.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I ſee Youth's raſh and inconſiderate,
It was the giddie factious multitude,
Not he (my Boyes) intruded on my right.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Con. Sir, we ſubmit.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Haſte then without delay,
To grace the Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We obey.

div.head: Act 1. Scen. 4.
div.stage: Enter Rodolphus, Magnus, Frederick in Priſon.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: And is the Emperours promiſe come to this?
Is this his Liberty?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: A Princes word
I took to be, as true as Heaven it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: For this I'le n'ere believe a Conqueſt more,
But what ſhall meet me over eares in bloud.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: 'Twas not we feared death as to be thought
Fooliſhly laviſh of our lives: to fight
For that liberty, we might have with peace.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Would we had dyed before we yeilded.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Hark! They ſing and dring within.

l.hi: Here's to that Noble Soul;
Drowns his ſins in a Bowl;
And cares not a fig for the Pope.
Here's to him a full Glaſſs,
That counts him an Aſſe,
Who will ſtinch at the ſight of the Rope.

sp.speaker: All within.
sp.l: Ho Boyes!

sp.speaker: Firſt.
sp.l: A merry life and a ſhort.
About with it.
Where lyes the fault?
Roger 'tis your liquor.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: O plague, I drank the very laſt but one,
Ralph wants it.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: O Brave Roarers! They know no other prayers.
Theſe are their Mattins, and their Evening Songs.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Is there ſuch mirth in death?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Or are they rather
Glad that the friendly Halter ſhortly will
Free them from Goal, which I count worſe then death.
VVhat man that hath that Noble thing call'd Soul
But hates confinement? This whole world would be
To narrow for him, were he alwaies tied to'r.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: But theſe poor ſouls are hardned in their Irons.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I was in hopes that breach like to have bin
Betwixt the Emperour and the Pope of late,
Would have made our way out

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: But that's all daſh't.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Could not our old friend (Otho having got
Into ſuch favour) do us here a kindneſs?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: We are but here kept like Weſt-Indian captives,
To be devoured at ſome ſolemn meeting,
With Mirth and Jollitie; endure't who liſt
Let our wits work our freedom

sp.speaker: Ro. Fred.
sp.l: We'l all aſſiſt.

div.head: Act. 1. Scen. 5.
div.stage: Enter Aurelia, Silvia, to them Sophrona, Matilda, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: May not one gueſſe affection by a glance?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Madam!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: 'Twas but one look, and that look did it.
Thoſe lights like Archimedes burning-glaſſe
Set me on Fire at that diſtance from him.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Your meaning, Madam.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Sylvia, thou art dull,
I ſee, for hadſt thou any ſence at all,
How couldſt thou chooſe but feel the ſelf-ſame heat?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Explain your ſelf, pray Madam.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Then I will.
I'me conquer'd by my Fathers Captive.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Which?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Now I could chide thee for a ſilly Gitle:
Doſt ask me which?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Otho's fair, Frederick ſmiling.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I ſee my errour. Love is ſuch a madneſs;
What we love, we'd have all love; and yet can't
Endure a Rival: Didſt not mind him Sylvia
With the Majeſtick countenance? My love
Is not Effeminate, although a Womans.

l.hi: Bold Magnus!
Magnus!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: In your cheeks I read it,
That bluſh betraies you; He is—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Huſh the Empreſs.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Aurelia! Why were you wanting at
The ſport but now?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Madam I was juſt comming.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Twas excellent, I love to ſee men active.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: They're gon to viſit now the Saxon Captives,
Nothing that's tending to your Fathers glory,
Muſt be concealed from theſe noble ſtrangers.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Muſt Magnus make them ſport?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Pray Madam!

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: What ſaith Aurelia? What's that Sylvia?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: She's ſorry, Madam, ſhe ſhould looſe the ſport.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I thought 'twould trouble her, there's more behind,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: But Madam, ſhall we never viſit Rome?

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: We may perchance, Matilda, danger it
Now there is made this happy reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I long to ſee his Holyneſs, methinks
I fancy moſt thoſe by Religion ty'd
From luſt and wedlock; am (you muſt concieve)
A chaſt Platonick Lover.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What is that?
To Love, to love, and not to enjoy?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Fruition
Doth but allay thoſe hightned flames, which are
The very life of love.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I am but raw,
(Yet give me leave) you ſeem, as if Matilda
You own'd no Paradiſe to ſcorching Aetna.
Platonick loves, (like Purgatorian ſires)
Doe but prepare us for a perfect bliſſe,
And make us worthy of a free poſſeſſion.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Aurelia, have a care my Girle, I fear
By your Romantick tongue, you may be ſmitten.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: If my diſcourſe offend (my Royal Mother)
May I be ever ſilent rather then
Provoke your hand.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You do miſtake the Empreſs.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: No matter, keep her ſtill in Ignorance.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Ours is but talk, Madam, you'l pardon it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: It is Ingenious, I gladly could
Hear more on't: but I dare believe by this
They are return'd. 'Tis high time to be gon,
We muſt be all there: This night puts anen'd
To the Solemnity.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We ſhall attend.

div.head: Act. II. Scen. I.
div.stage: Enter Pope, Card. Victor, other Cardinals, Attendants. The Pope aſcends his Chair.

sp.speaker: Ʋict.
sp.l: God ſave Pope Gregory the Seventh! All. Long live!

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: Caeſar confirmes it!

sp.speaker: Pope.
sp.l: Who's that mentions Caeſar?
For Policie I did complie a while,
It was but to procure the ſurer ground,
To give the Emperour the ſtronger blow.
Muſt Peter ſtoop to Caeſar?

sp.speaker: 2 Card.
sp.l: That reſts fully,
Sir, in your Holineſs to remedy.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: My Keys already look and unlock Heaven,
And if they wont fit, I will add a ward
Wherewith they ſhall ſerve Earthly Kingdoms,
To make and unmake Princes at my pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Nobly Reſolv'd, Sir, This will grace your See,
With the more awe and ſplendour.

sp.speaker: 2. Car.
sp.l: And reſtore
Rome to itsformer fame, that it ſhall be
Once more the worlds renown'd Metropolis.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: Henry's accuſ'd—

sp.speaker: Pope.
sp.l: I may as well ask him
Forgivneſs of my ſins, as to be Pope.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: He needeth pardon, Sir, or puniſhment,
Who is ſo loudly tax'd for a truce-breaker.

sp.speaker: 2. Card.
sp.l: The Saxons gladly would help to depoſe him.

sp.speaker: 1. Card.
sp.l: A Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Cruel, Symoniacal,
A buiſie Bodger of Church-livings, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pope.
sp.l: I hear enough: makes him uncapable,
Both of Heavens mercy, and of mans protection.
Let him be Excommunicated! leſſe
Cannot be done to him, doth ſo tranſgreſſe.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: All things ſucceed as well as heart could wiſh.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: So, this is ſomewhat towards my Journey now.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What haſt thou there Jocoſo?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Nothing Sir,
But a peice for killing an good old woman,
That did ſo lave the houſe ſtill with her noſe
As ſhe ſwept it.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Didſt it accurately.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: To a hair, Sir, no Juggler ever playd
Legerdemaine neater, then I ſhook that ſame
Into her Hallow tooth.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: And is ſhe dead?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Dead, and at heaven I hope. Her ſon was mad
For haſte to bury her the Ruſhian faſhion,
With Hoſe and Shoes, ſhe was ſo troubleſome
To the chymney-corner (he ſaid) and liv'd
So unmercifully, to keep that little
She had from him.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: 'Twas he then gave the peice.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: It was, and to ſay truth, I well deſerv'd it.
It did ſo plague me Sir, to hatch a cry,
And pray an hours nonſence by the clock.
I muſt not touch her, if I touch'd abook.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I warrant 'twas one of thoſe good women
That uſ'd to fetch an ill contrived ſigh
At Church, in the wrong place; (not hearing well)

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: She was, all ſaid, hugely well given Sir,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: And ſo art thou, nay if thou canſt Jocoſo
Fanatick-like, murder with prayers and teares,
N'ere fear a livelyhood Joc. and when thy • orks done,
My Fee will make me a Thanks-giving day.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: All ſuch odd jobs I give thee.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Come haſten, fetch our things, we muſt be gon.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Now the Popes Licence without peradventure
Will be excepted from the Emperour
To gain me leave, (ſince they are both agreed)
To practice near his Court: My man may play
At lower ſtakes, and kill men for a triſle:
But where I venture Soul, Life and Eſtate,
It ſhall, believe me, coſt a ſaucie rate.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: What! we are likely to be all to peices
Agen, Honorio, with the Emperour.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: So the newes goes, and the Popes Arrogance
Hath raiſ'd a civil warre amongſt the Clergy.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am reſolv'd I'le be of no religion
Till all agree.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: I muſt confeſs theſe failings
Shew they'r but men, but what they'd have us learn,
Is of an higher and diviner nature,
In that themſelves ſo hardly practice it.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I cannot blame the German Biſhops
To ſtand for their cuſtome and prerogative.
Is there no Patriarchal ſeat but Rome?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I'me apt to think they ſhortly will determine
No Baptiz'd Infant, ſhall be call'd a Chriſtian
Except his Name be Peter.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Can there be
Nothing decreed without the Pope Prudentio?
Ought he, and only he, command a Council,
How, where, and when, he pleaſe?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: This is in Truth,
Novel Encroachment, and he's like to ſmart for't,
Should the Prelates now joyn with th' Emperour.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Would they were at it once.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Will you engage?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: There's nothing better, Boy, then Wars or Women,
To tame this Fact, and I abhor a Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: The better Warriour.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Thoſe deſperate Dam-hims
Who for a while may force the fare of Valour.
To ſtand a prick or two in vindicating
Their Ladyes naughty title to her Honour,
(To gain ſome Commendation, or a kindneſs)
Can never ſerve their Country worth a ruſh.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Why now I like you: Gentlemen, your Hands,
You'l ſide with me.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: May we elſe never ſpeed:

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Reſolve then for the Emperour.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Agreed.

div.head: Act. 2. Scen. 4.
div.stage: Enter Magnus to him Otho, Frederick.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Can her ſoft nature ſport with th' afflicted?
I'le never think it, this were to blaſpheme
Thy love Aurelia! She comes.—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I'le try him, Sylvia.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: 'Tis prudence!

sp.speaker: Magnus!
sp.l: I bring enlargemen and delight to be
The early meſſenger of welcome newes.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: All thanks kind Princeſs: Madam you are noble:
Your Preſence is a freedome.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yours a Priſon.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I ſee I was but mockt; What Scenes are theſe?
Such Calmes and Tempeſts in the ſelf-ſame breath
Am I offenſive?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: You have mov'd him Madam.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yes, and Love-Sympathy now makes me ſuffer
A double torture, Magnus! Imuſt—

div.stage: Drawes & gives her his Sword. aſide to Silvia, gives him his Sword.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Here is a Weapon, if you muſt diſpatch me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: He ſtill miſaprenends me Sylvia,
And how undauntedly he talks of death!
Dear Magnus! ſheath, the Priſon that I talkt of
Was nothing elſe but loves enſnarement.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Now,
You ſurfet me with joy, tell't by peice-meales.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: My Fathers purpoſe is to ſet you free.

sp.speaker: Magnus
sp.l: I owe it you.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Heaven bleſs theſe meeting flames.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Some German Princes lately proving Rebels,
Joyn with the Saxons now agen in Armes.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: You Noble Magnus muſt be one of us.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Swear Loyaltie t'aſſiſt the Emperour.
Thy Valour's know.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: If I muſt take this oath,
I'le go and bid the Saxons, fight and help 'um;
And then return and willingly ſubmit
To that juſt death my perjury deſerves.
I'le prove as falſe to you, as to my Country.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Sir you'r unhandſome to your Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Sylvia,
sp.l: what was't he ſaid? He'd prove as falſ
To me as to his Country, was't not ſo?
This is no ſlighting but doth argue rather
That ſtrong and holy zeal he hath for both.
I like him better for this Reſolution,
His Conſtancy to me and that together
Muſt ſind a way He may be falſ to neither.

div.head: Act. 2. Scen. 5.
div.stage: Enter Emperour, Sophrona, Matilda, Henry, Conrade, Otho. Attendants.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Were't not for theſe Apoſtatizing Germans
The Pope ſhould feel by ſad Experience,
No curſe ſo heavy, as a Princes anger.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Theſe Rebels muſt be look'd to timely Sir,

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I firſt muſt make my peace with Rome; or elſe
His Holyneſs will have in every Corner,
Blind zealots, that will ſtrive by murdering me
To merit Heaven:

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Can man be thought ſo ſtupid?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O Madam! Ignorance leads to all miſcheif.
This makes ſome bid good marrow to a Snaile,
Or Serpent, and Adore 'um for that day;
The Vulgar learn Rebellion ſtill without book,
Which the Pope ſhuts and bids 'um read their Leſſons
In his commands, which needs muſt be (he ſaith)
Alwaies Infallible.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I ſee Matilda,
Thou art Ingenious, and talkſt handſomly.
( • ogether with the Empreſs) I have thought on
Employment for you.

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: May we ſerve you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thus 〈◊〉 I beg this Houour.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Riſe, 'tis granted.
Haſt courage thinkſt, to face his Holyneſs?

sp.speaker: Sop.
sp.l: Thou'rt like now to enjoy thy wiſh Matilda.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: You ſee, my Boyes, Princes are ſomtimes made
The Tennis-balls of Fortune, to be bandy'd
At her unconſtant pleaſure; now full fraught
With good ſucceſs, ſoon after wrackt with croſſes.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Sir! we are raſh and inconſiderate.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He firſt uſurp'd the Mitre, then ask'd leave.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: My Children blame me Otho, that I did not
Tread upon Hildebrands ſubmiſſive neck.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: You were more Noble, Sir, and Mercyful,
Who could have thought on ſuch Hypocriſy?

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: We muſt not now ſpend all our time in talk,
Aurelia is to tender for this Journey.
Henry, and Conrade, you'r iuclin'd to travel.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: We muſt Sir, if it be your Royal pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Sophrona, you, and you, Matilda ſhall
Receive your charge anon.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: With diligence.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Otho, to you we ſhall commend the care
Of our affairs at Home.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: I ſhall be faithful.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: The Sun ſometimes is darkned with Ecclipſes;
And the moſt fixed Stats do ſeem to twinkle;
So muſt my ſplendour for a while be clouded:
And I! The Pilgrim-Prince, now plainly ſhew,
Monarchs, like Tides, do Ebb, as well as Flow.

div.head: Act. 3. Scen. 1,
div.stage: Enter Aurelia, Sylvia, to them Otho, Magnus, Frederick, Rodolphus.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: The powers above muſt needs approve our love.
Their ſecret wiſdome doth ſo proſper it.
How Melancholy would the Court be now?
Were it nor for, you know my meaning Sylvia.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Madam, for ſome divertiſement, let's go
To ſee the Mask acted to day.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Agreed.
And let us go diſguiſ'd without Attendants.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Aurelia you are Queen we'l only act
At your command, now in your Fathers abſence.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You'r Gen'rous. Then my firſt endeavour's for
Some worthy Honour on your Countrey men.
(For your ſake Otho) what ſhall Magnus be?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Thanks to our Noble Viceroy, I enjoy,
A Happineſs ample enough in my
Freedome from Priſon, and that Oath I hated.
But cheiſly, Madam, in your government.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: This is handſome, I fear I come to late.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: What ſhall be Magnus? Nothing for Rodolphus.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Nor Frederick.

sp.speaker: Rod.
sp.l: We'l make our ſelves, when once
We come i'th' field, good Otho, give us quickly
Some Martial Office or our Swords will ruſt.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: We'l meet to night (if it may pleaſe the Princeſs!)
In Council, where we all may know our charge.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You may Command it Sir.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We ſhall attend.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Madam you are forgetful.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Now we'l go.
Moſt Noble Viceroy I muſt crave your leave
This afternoon to take ſome private repaſt.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Madam, you degrade your ſelf to ask it.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I in my Fathers abſence owe you dutie.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Might I entreat your Love it were an Honour.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You cannot chooſe but have it in obedience.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Adeiu ſweet Princeſs.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Yours

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Farewell Sylvia.
I am reſolv'd Harrie ſhall ne're come here,
Nor his two Sons; yet we uſurpers love
To guild our Titles with ſome ſhew of • ight.
There is but one lett and I'le ſtraight remove it.
Aurelia could I once make thee my own,
I were for ever ſtabliſh'd in my Throne.

div.head: Act, 3. Scen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Brazutus and Jocoſo, there appears an Apothecharies ſhop.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Dull times Jocoſo.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: They can never hold.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Why Prethee.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: I Faith if they do Maſter,
I muſt like the Peruvian Cannibals,
Feaſt it with mans fleſh, and it muſt be mine own.
Cur Collops here, Sir, and be merry with 'um
They'l aſt as long as I, and ther's an end.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Thou talkſt too frolick, to be ſtarv'd Jocoſo.
I am already got into their faſhion,
Who make their meals either with Mear, or Drink,
Not both together, our trade won't maintain it.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My takings are but ſmall, the warrs ſpoil all.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Pox on it, Men are grown both hard, and holy;
I would now murder, half as cheap agen
As I did formerly, to gain ſome cuſtome.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: My takings too lye all in Preſervations,
Were it not for the French—

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: I have obſerv'd
That is the prettieſt ſtrang diſtemper Maſter,
It like a cunning Gameſter hath its ſalf paſs,
Makes at the lower parts, and hits the Noſe.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: And then there's fine work that will pay us well.
T' erect a new bridg, or uphold the old one.
Here comes a Cuſtomer.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: What want you Sir?

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Dwells here Brazutus?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: There's my Maſter Sir.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: A word or two in private.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I ſhall Sir.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: O pox! I warrant he's pepper'd by's ſtradling.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Are we not ſomewhat of the lateſt Sylvia?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Madam, they ſay it don't begin till four.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Let us make haſte.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: What want you Ladies, pray?
Here dweleth that Renowned Don Brazutus,
That moſt famous Italian Phyſitian.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Heaven bleſs me, is not Otho yonder whiſpering?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: The very ſame, what makes he here ſo private?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I ſtrang! paſs on, he cannot know us Sylvia.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Thoſe two paſt by, were pretty Girles I ſware
If thoſe Faces I ſaw were all their own.
But if they were, they are not for our purpoſe:
We cannot live, but by good Gentlewomen,
That undreſs Nature, as they dreſs to bed.
At night throw off their Perewigs, and their Noſes.
Pull out their Teeth, and lay aſide their Eies.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I warrant Sir.

div.stage: Jocoſo orders his things in his ſhop.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: There is on other way
But this to gain Aurelia, and prepare
A free and valid paſſage to my ſuit.
Her carriage I confeſs ſeems plauſible,
Yet it is nothing but Diſſimulation.
Did not I ſee which way her amorous eye went,
And how 'twas only fix'd on him? Brazutus,
Be quick and private.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: As your own breaſt Sir.
I am beholding to my good old Maſter.
The Pope hath taught me here a bleſſed Leſſon.
Now Mental Reſervation, ſaves my neck,
And no way hurts my Purſe, I'le out with all:
Should ſhe love Magnus, as I am perſwaded,
Aurelia's pay will excel that of Otho's.
Jocoſo, Let's go in I'le give thee, Boy,
One point of Wine, to chear thee, theſe ſad times.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: My Maſter hath a peice, I warrant you
He is ſo free, this look'd like a good chapman,
A curſe upon this Primogeniture!
But a few minutes create all this trouble;
My Elder Brother carries all the Land,
And I may feed on Gallipots, and glaſſes.
Before I'le ſtarve thus like a ſilly Elfe,
I am a Knave, if I don't Hang my ſelf

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: The Emperour's arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Fully Incenſ'd I gueſs
Againſt the Pope.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: We'l tame this mad uſurper.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: I wiſh, Honorio, this Religious Rebel,
Were well chaſtiſ'd.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: If his Revenge be dull,
We'l whet his ſword, Sir, with our active ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Firſt, we muſt underſtand the Princes mind,
Before we be to forward, Junio.
Only we'l give him leave to pick our meaning,
And our deſignes, out of our coſtly banquets,
And bounteous Entertainments.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: He ſhall read
Theſe civil diſcords in the neat-wrought Sweet meats.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: I am not for theſe womans toyes, but if
The Wine be good, I'le carouſe wholeones to Him,
And Fancy the Pope merrily tumbling down.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: This is a ſharp and bitter ſeaſon for 'um.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I hear the Empreſs comes, and her two Sons
With a moſt Noble Train of handſome Ladies.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: They do not come, I hope, to fight with theſe.
If any thing doth make me run away,
'Twill be a womans ſhreicks.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Ill, and harſh ſounds
But you can't hear 'um, for the Drums and Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: They will ſecure theſe in the Littadel.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Poor ſouls! It can't but be hard ſerviſe to 'um.
They never ſaw ſuch weather in their Chambers,
Which they do alwaies keep this winter quarters.
They know no Snow, but what their Waſh-ball makes,
Nor Ice, but curious artificial Jellies:
Bold Boreas will diſturb this Lock, that Curle,
So put them to't.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Shame on their tenderneſs!
If I marry it ſhall de ſome Amazon,
Can fight with one hand, and give ſuck with t'other.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: For all your merry talking, Gentlemen,
Let's not be tardy to ſalute the Prince.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: True, they deſerve our early loves. No age,
Can Parrallel, this Royal Pilgrimage.

div.head: Act. 3. Scen. 4.

sp.speaker: Pope.
sp.l: I'le be as frigid to him as the Alpes,
And the deep winter, now they travel in.

sp.speaker: Ʋict.
sp.l: Make him your Slave, Dread Sir, to hold your Stirrop:
Give him a good cuff if he don't do't right.

sp.speaker: 1 Card.
sp.l: Tread on him Sir, when you get up your Horſe.

sp.speaker: Pope.
sp.l: I now can make him any thing or nothing.
Having him in a treble twiſt; I hear,
The German Biſhops back my cenſure, and
Their Princes wont comply, without my pardon.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Sir The Embaſſy's come.

sp.speaker: Pope.
sp.l: Admit them quickly,
Their Sex commands civil Reſpect, from all.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Thus low we begg your Honour.

div.stage: Sop. & Mat. kneel & kiſs his Toe.

sp.speaker: Pope.
sp.l: Your Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Your Emperour layes his Scepter at your feet.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Is't come to this? It was but lately, I
Muſt ask Him leave to put my Mitre on.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sir, we appeal to you, as unto Heaven,
For Clemency, abſtract from all revenge,
Or any thought on't.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: True. Yet ſinners muſt
Know by our frowns wherein they have offended.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: This he doth well, Sir, and is humbled for it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: If there be merit (next your Holynes)
What can be Higher then a Princes Faſting?

sp.speaker: Soph,
sp.l: Three daies already, all diſrob'd, and bare-foot.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: We have paſſed through the Iſland Purgatory,
In our cold progreſs; nor grudge we this penance,
T'arrive at Bliſs, wee mean, your Holyneſs;
Where 'twere not Venial now, to doubt of Mercy,
For which I cannot but adore your preſence.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: She cannot be deny'd, this Ladies converſe
Becomes a Patriarch, 'tis ſo ſublime:
Let's go conferre about this buiſnes.

sp.speaker: Ʋict.
sp.l: Gladly.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Madam, for your ſakes I will think upon
Some termes of Pardon, (may they be accepted)
You ſhall anon receive • um privately.

sp.speaker: So. Mat.
sp.l: You Crown our wiſhes.

sp.speaker: So.
sp.l: I'le run with this newes.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Privately! Let me ſee! a well-thought Lady,
Muſt act a ſubtle niceneſs, to keep up
Her reputation, whatſoere ſhe prove,
Were He another man, this might create
An ill conception of me: but I hope
There can be no ſuch danger, in the Pope,

div.head: Act. 1. Scen. 5.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I wonder Conrade, what th' effect will be.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Had I but had my wiſh, it never ſhould
Have come to this.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: You ſee th' Italian Princes
Receive us Nobly, take no notice, Conrade,
At all, of th' Execration.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I have that
Within my breaſt, cannot abide there long:
It ſwells to faſt.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Prethee declare what is it?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Will you ſwear ſecrecy, and courage then?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I dare to you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You ſhall be Emperour,
My Father dotes.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: We will divide this Honuor.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I'le ask no more, and— They come.

div.stage: Enter Pope, Victor, Cardinals, Sophrona, Matilda, Ladies, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Let us ſtand here, this is the privateſt.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Let him b' admitted with his Royal Habet,
And order that a Banquet be prepar'd
Without delay.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: That's better then his bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: You ſee now Ladies, how my full deſires
Do well concurre with yours in act of grace.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Thanks to your Holyneſs we find it ſo.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: It well becomes, Sir, your Paternal Bowels.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Your Honour, (with the Emperours Pietie)
Doth ſtand engag'd, Matilda, to ſecure
The Juſt performance of what's offered.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: VVhat'ere is mine, Sir, may it be thought worthy,
I'le freely ſtake to have your will fullfil'd.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: I know thou 'rt Noble, if thou fancy'ſt Rome
Command our Court.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: This is exact Love-talk.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: In my heart the old fellow will prove wanton,

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I muſt perforce awhile diſſemble it
Thanks Holy Father.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This is brave ſubmiſſion.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: You have our Abſolution, and our Love.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Heaven proſper, and continue theſe embraces!

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Let us refreſh our ſelves! Fall to, Matilda.

l.hi: Muſick playes and they ſing within.
Your Civil jarrs
Are the worſt Warrs:
But now ſuch dangers ceaſe:
Thoſe Mortal Gods,
That were at odds,
Conclude an happie Peace.
It is moſt pleaſant Harmonie,
When Crown and Mitre do agree.
We all then fear
Sad darkneſs near,
When Heaven's Two great Lights fight:
Whil'ſt Prince and Pope
Claſh; there's no hope,
But the worlds fatal night.
But 'tis moſt pleaſant Harmonie,
When Crown and Mitre do agree.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I ſee the Cardinals Caps are good for ſomwhat.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: They hold almoſt a Charger full of March-paines.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Your Bounty hath oblig'd us, Sir.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Accept it.
Now our next buiſneſs, is to confirm all
Before the Sacred Alter.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We attend you.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: The face of things, methinks, ſeemes but untowardly,
I do not like it, Conrade, Peace can never
Sute with the nature, and complexion
Of our deſignes, our ſport muſt be in Tempeſts.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I warrant you, rather then baulk the action,
If we find diſcords ſlow, we'l make a faction.

div.head: Act. 4. Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Brazutuss, Jocoſo, as on a Stage.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Now Maſter ther's hopes of a Trade agen,
Things fadge ſo well at Rome.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: We ſhall anon
Have company.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: I find the Market mends.
The Clowns begin to draw their Cat-ſtring Purſes,
And call ſo boldly for a Pot for Joane.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: They droop'd but now, I ſaw, moſt heavily,
With their Chops leaning on their Staves, a liſtning,
And enquiring of every one they met,
Whether they thought this War would cauſe a Land Tax.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: But now they are as brisk.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: We'l try their Pockets.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: 'Tis never well but when the Glove goes, Maſter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The Empreſs will I hear honour our ſport.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: I'le leap out of my skin, and in agen.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I ſtrange they tarry.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Pox on't nothing, but
Two bawling fellowes on a Ladder yonder,
Detain 'um: now they come.

sp.speaker: 1. Wo.
sp.l: Yonder he is.

sp.speaker: 2. Wo.
sp.l: Look, Jack ſhall ſee him.

sp.speaker: 3. Wo.
sp.l: Poor Knave, what ailes He?

sp.speaker: 2. Wo.
sp.l: Alaſs woman he hath had an Ague this ſix weeks.
They ſay this Monſter-banke knowes what's good for't.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Gentlemen, By the help of a Divine hand, I can Cure all thoſe Diſtempers, mentioned in your Paper, I need not name them. Only I am to tell you, amongſt the reſt, there is a Rare Jeſuitical Powder, made of the skin of the Serpent the Devil poſſeſſed, when he ſeduced Eve. That outwardly applyed, will charm away any Ague, be it Tertian, Quartan, on Quotidian.

sp.speaker: 2. Wo.
sp.l: I am glad of that.

p.hi: I purchaſ'd it by my Intimacy at Rome, the Great-great-grandmother of all Antiquity. No one elſe hath it.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Maſter mind me

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The price of all my things.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Maſter my things!

p.hi: The price of all my things, with the Directory how to uſe them, is Three Shillings.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Maſter!

p.hi: But becauſe my time is not long with you, I ſhall in love give you ſix pence.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Maſter, my things!

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: So that you ſhall have all mine, and Jocoſo's for three ſhillings in the whole,

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: With my Balls you may ſcrub up old Cloathes and Faces, and make them look like new.

sp.speaker: 1. Wo.
sp.l: Give me the whole parcel.

sp.speaker: 2. Wo.
sp.l: And me.
And me.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: My Balls help a wench to a husband quickly.
The take away all ſcurff, ſcabs and wrinckles,
redneſs, freckles, pimples, or any unhandſomneſs in the fleſh.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Gentlemen, if any of you be rich enough for the Gout, you muſt know I wrought an incomparable Cure of this lately, in Italy, on the Popes great Toe.

div.stage: Enter a Drunken-man reeling amongſt them.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Drunk.
sp.l: What a pox do all theſe Fooles harkning to a couple of Knaves?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: You make a gleak of us Gaffer.

sp.speaker: Drunk.
sp.l: Are you minded to have your po. po. Pockets pickt?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: You'r an old Rogue.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Friend, about your buiſneſs.

sp.speaker: Drunk.
sp.l: Kiſs my Bumme.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Were I a little nearer, my foot ſhould ſweetly.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Mind him not pray, He's Drunk, Sir.

sp.speaker: Drunk.
sp.l: Kiſs my Bumme!

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: I'de drum a march on't.

sp.speaker: Drunk.
sp.l: Kiſs my Bu, Bu, Bumme!

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Good now be quiet.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Were not this fellow drunk now, Gentlemen,
I'de make him a ſad example, we come not
Here, Sirs, without leave from the Emperour.
And a full Licenſe from his Holineſs.
Diſpatch Jocoſo.

div.stage: Enter on the Stage an old Woman holding her Teeth.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: I have done! Here com's an object of Charity.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Pray Sir!

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Set down good woman.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Which Tooth is it? She hath but that.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: 'Tis Ha, Hallow Sir.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: It makes your breath ſtinck.
'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: I find eaſe.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: You have eaſ'd nature I think.

sp.speaker: Wo.

l.hi: ſmells the tooth.

sp.l: What muſt you have.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: I have enough alreadie.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Pray Sir ſpeak!

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Don't drop Curt'ſies ſo, for fear your Curt'ſies drop.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: I'de willingly content you.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Good goodwife-houſe-of-Office do not follow me, ſo!

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: You muſt ſpeak in my ear, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Oh hell! muſt I come ſo near her. I'le have nothing Gammer!

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Thank you, Sir, I am deaf.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Pox on her, ſhe hath neither eares, nor noſe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: This goes now 'mongſt my Regiment of Teeth.
Each one (like thoſe, I read, which Cadmus ſow'd,
May prove a Man of reputation.
sp.stage: pulls his cloath out & ſhews it.
sp.l: Do you not here, Sir, read a learned Artiſt,
As well, as in thoſe ſixteen ſtragling Letters
He brought to Greece? And now kind Gentlemen
Be pleaſ'd to walk in, (Hang me if I lye)
You ſhall ſee wonders of Activity.

div.head: Act. 4. Scen. 2.
div.stage: Enter Emperour, Prudentio, Honorio, Iunio. To them Henry, Conrade.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: For you we had deſign'd our lives and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: This is an everlaſting Infamie,
Sir, to your Royal Empire.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: He's a Lecher.
A murderer, and by lewd practiſes
Set on the Papacie.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Had my dull Braine,
From your firſt kindneſs apprehended you,
This nere had bin.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: In you were all our hopes,
Whom we eſteem'd the Patron of all Juſtice,
The Alter and ſole Bulwark of the Lawes

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: We valu'd not his Excommunication.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Thoſe civil diſcords of the German Prinsce
Forc'd me to get this off, on ſuch conditions,
Hell's Torment's nothing to 'um. I muſt ſtand
To the Popes Judgment; Anſwer mine accuſers:
If guilty, quietly reſign my Crowns,
In the mean time, live privately: releaſe
My Subjects from their Loyaltie, and Oath.
And which is worſt, never attempt revenge.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: But that good manners here conſtrain'd a patience
I had not heard you half out, 'twas ſuch pain.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: He ſtrives in all this but t' enſlave you to him.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: And works his pleaſure on you, thus diſarm'd.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: We'r Idle ſtill.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Our Swords ſhall cut this League.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: The Soul can be oblidg'd to nothing, but
What's free, and voluntary.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Sir, we hear
Otho Rebels, and with a num'rous Army
Bids you defiance.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Aided with Rodolphus.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: More Miſchief! Your aſſiſtance Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: 'Tis ready, Sir, moſt willingly.

sp.speaker: Hen. & Con.
sp.l: And ours.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Firſt we'l ſecure Home, next ſucceeds thy doome,
Thy doome, Proud Metropolitan of Rome.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Prepare all things in order for the Bath.
I hope by this your perfect in your Task.

sp.speaker: 1 Lad.
sp.l: VVe are, Dear Madam,
And are happy in 'um.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Obſerve your charge, I follow.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We obey.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: 'Tis fine! the whole world is at my command.
Although I cannot bear the name of Pope,
I have the power fully, under him.
This Duke, that Cardinal, this Lord, that Abbot,
Are all my Creatures, owe me ſute and ſerviſe.
All the Revenues of Rome's Mother-Church
Are ſcarce enough now, to maintain a Miſtreſs.
A Lady well dreſt, like a Perſ'an Madam
VVares ſev'ral cityes on her; ſo muſt I.
The Peter Pence will find me Pins and Laces.
And —

sp.speaker: Pope
sp.l: What alone, at thy private contemplations?
Let none confeſs thee but my ſelf, Matilda.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sir, you beſt know my ſecret paſſions.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: I doe, and can beſt pardon 'um.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your Cardinals.
I muſt retire till anon.

sp.speaker: Pope.
sp.l: Your buiſneſs.

sp.speaker: Ʋict.
sp.l: Sir, Th' Emperour is ſtarted from his Cov'nant
Already, and with th' Italian Nobles
Conſpire your ruine.

sp.speaker: Pope.
sp.l: Moſt unheard of falſhood!
We muſt beſtir us to be ready for 'um.
Here now I want my good old Freind Brazutus.
Can't we put confidence in Alter-vowes?
Nay; If once ſuch Aſſurances be croſt
As Theſe; I'le burn the conſecrated Hoſt.

div.head: Act. 4. Scen. 4.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Sirs, Now, now, let's behave our ſelves like men!
The ſtak's the Cerman Empire, and we'l ſhare it,
Amongſt us three: we'l ſhare it equallie.

div.stage: Enter Above Emp. Hen. Con. Ho. Pru. Jun.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Will you yeild Traytors?

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: If yo'have valour for it.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Ye ſhall have mercy.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Dandle Fools and Children.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: Kingdoms are more worth then to part with ſo.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Force the doores open, Sirs.
We have free entrance.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Magnus is poyſon'd Otho, and his Ghoſt
Comes to revenge his Death.

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Villain, I am cheated.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.l: We are betray'd!

div.stage: A noiſe within, they run, they run, they run.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: They come like lightning on us!

div.stage: Enter Hen. Con. Mag. beating Otho, Fred. Rodolp. off the Stage,

sp.speaker: Otho.
sp.l: Stand to't Rodolphus.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Now

div.stage: Enter Junio, and Honorio, with their Swords rawn.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Pox on't! they fled, fore I had half my ſill.
Such wars as theſe ſtarve a good ſtomackt Sword

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: They had good Heels. The Emperour's ſafe I ſee.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Prudentio Thanks! Thanks to you Noble Sirs!
To you we owe this conqueſt.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: To your Courage.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: And VViſdom, Sir, we muſt aſcribe this Honour.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Pox! 'Twas a skirmiſh not worth talking of.

l.hi: Magnus!

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: The Three-Head-Traytors have their due deſerts,
Rodolphus, Sir, and Frederick are ſlain
By the theſe your Noble Sons.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: VVas this your Act, My Boyes?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Faith fine Beginnings, Hah, Honorio.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Thanks to good Fortune, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: They're modeſt too.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Now Gentlemen, your ſwords have carv'd your way
To a moſt free, and well-deſerved welcome,
To what 'ere Germany affords.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: All thanks.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I long almoſt to ſee Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: She'l not a little triumph at this news.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Mag. Do you conduct the Empreſs to us.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Sir, I obey.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Let's go.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We all attend.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Ill luck, the old man ſcap'd ſo, were He dead
We'd never talk of Primogeniture.
But be ſworn Collegues in the Empire, Conrade.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Here we were forc'd to fight, to help to ſave him,
We, and our hopes elſe had been loſt for ever,
But now there is an other Warre behind,
May order all things, Harrie, to our mind.

div.head: Act. 4. Scen. 5.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Are you reſolv'd to Antidate his death,
And weep his Dirge, before hand, Madam?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I ſaw him murder'd, in my dream laſt night,
And felt the ſword that did it, Sylvia!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Theſe be but idle Fancies; He's alive!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: He's run through (here I bleed) He's run through here!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: A Meſſenger! what Newes!

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Where's the Princeſs?
Madam!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I have but a few minutes now!

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Your Royal Father hath the Victory.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: How would I fain know, what I fear to know!

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Madam! The Empreſs with the two young Princes
Are ſafe returned.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Still Impertinent!

sp.speaker: Meſs.
sp.l: And —

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Now it comes! quick rid me out of pain.
Speak, how doth Magnus?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: They are all at hand.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: He knows not Magnus, Madam! Now they come.

div.stage: Enter Emp. Sophrona, Magnus, Prudentio, Honorio, Junio.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: And now I ſee him Sylvia, or his Ghoſt.
Your Royal Bleſſings both!

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: The Heavens preſerve
My Dear Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: How doſt, my Child?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Thanks Royal Mother: How is't Magnus?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Sir, you much Honour us to ſhew ſuch Treaſure.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Is not ſhe tempting, Junio?

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: In her Sex.
You know I mind no face but what's in Breeches,
And ſo may make a fit Companion,
For Mars, or Bachus, Fighting, boy, or Drinking.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Sirs, you ſhall taſt our Liquor, and accept
A large Heart, with a ſlender Entertainment.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Oh Sir, you all oblige us by your kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: 'Twas to do ſomwhat that can ne're be done.
'Twas to do ſomwhat to deſerve Aurelia
And next you, to Revenge that Treacherie
I alwaies hated.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You were ever Noble

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Magnus is dead! don't he affright you Madam?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Surely thou art ſome Sybil, Sylvia.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Lives Aurelia?
And Sylvia too?

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Welcome ſweet Princes!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: VVhat,
You kil'd Rodolphus, and You Frederick.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And Magnus, Otho. Now ſhe bluſhes Conrade.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: 'Tis but your Fancy.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: VVe muſt not delay.
They will but juſt recruit, and then for Rome.
Come Siſter.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: VVe will follow. Sylvia!
Compoſe thy ſelf for Mirth, Girle!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I do, Madam,
And am prepar'd to frolick, any how
You ſhall Command.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: The Heavens n're ſmil'd, till now.

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter. Emperour, Prudentio, Honorio, Junio, Henry, Conrade.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Matilda! what means this? Read Gentlemen!
I am the Privy-Council of his breaſt
(She writes) Beware Brazutus! I live yet,
Free from all poyſon, don't I? Well Matilda,
Shall not repent this kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: This is he
Poyſon'd Seven Popes to make uſe of this.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Lives here Brazutus?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: And his Man Jocoſo.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Beggarly Urchin! He'l kill any one,
For a Pot, Ten-groats, and the dead corps in,
To make ſome Mummia for th' Apothecaries.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Were they for this, thus long allow'd our Court?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Sir, This was he, that ſhould have poyſon'd Magnus.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: To you we leave th'inſpection of this buiſneſs
Together Henry, with the government.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I ſhall be Juſt, Sir, May you ſafe return!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Be mindful of your promiſe Hal.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Conrade goes.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: We ſhall miſs his Valour elſe.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Thanks for your Noble thoughts Prudentio.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: Would we could flie Honorio to the wars
On ſome ſwift-whinged Horſes.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Oh brave Junio.

sp.speaker: Hen,
sp.l: Farewel! From this time ſhall my Raign take date,
Will Magnus ſecond now, this pleaſing Fate.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I fear'd thee Magnus, Magnus I did.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Dear Madam!
You that had got ſuch Intereſt in my heart,
Methinks ſhould know what's in't. Ther's truth written,
Not in dull Characters, but large, and laſting.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Enough!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Hymen cannot be wanting long.
(Madam) That bluſh did well become a Lady,
That muſt anon be chaſtly raviſhed.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Sylvia, you talk. The Empreſs.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Noble Magnus!

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Madam, was not your Journey tedious.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: 'Twas.
And now return'd we muſt confeſs, to you
We owe our ſelves and Kingdoms, and that eaſe
They do afford.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Didſt hear that Sylvia?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: This Honour juſtly appertains
To th' Emperour, and Your Heroick ſons.
Pray do 'um Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Courage never braggs.
Harrie how is't.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: I left 'um well, and merry.
Magnus a word or two with you, in ſecreet.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What's become of Matilda, Royal Mother?
That I was thus forgetful, not to ask
Till now.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: She's grown obſequious to the Pope,
And wants for nothing.

sp.speaker: Aur,
sp.l: Oh me! I thought him
Still paſt a woman, by the Papian Law.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: She talk'd indeed at firſt Amorouſly
Of the old Man.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: You ſay right Sylvia.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Aurelia's wiſe, chaſte, fair.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I know all this,
And yet I'le wedd my grave, firſt

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Farewel then.
Avoid the Court upon my high Diſpleaſure

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: They'r mov'd!

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: What means all this?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Let us enquire.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: My Joyes are Daſht ſtill, as they do begin
The Sun but juſt appear'd, and is clapt in.

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 3.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And let him flye! My pompe will be the ſame.
(My hopes are built upon undoubted grounds:)
Victor will be as good as Gregorie.
Command the Card'nals to recieve my pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Attend.
sp.l: We ſhall

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: How like you Sirs, my Dreſs to day?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: As it becomes the Empreſs of the world.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I know no reaſon for the Salique Law,
But that a woman may be fit to govern,
Or why do Poets talk of Juno Pallas.
Place pow'r and wiſdom in the Female Gender?
Had not dame Nature cut us out to Rule,
She never would have giv'n us ſuch deſires,
We'l give men leave to think we think them wiſe,
But yet we know our ſtrength: all States, and Perſons,
(Act we diſcreetly) may be conquered
By our well manag'd favours.

l.hi: Without. The day's our own.

div.stage: Enter Emp. Prudentio, Hon. Jun. Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Secure all there.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: The buiſneſs is effected.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: They can't be hir'd to turn agen: (Hare-like)
One Run a Poſt down, with his eies behind.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Make room-there, ſtand back

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: The Cardinals.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Great Sir! thus low accept my Loyalty.

sp.speaker: Emp,
sp.l: Matilda, riſe, we have ſufficient proof of't.
Fathful, and politick were thy deſignes
To which we owe this bloudleſs victory.
How may we now requite this love?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Our ſelves and ſervice, Sirs, muſt be our Princes
Pure from all Mercenarie purpoſes.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: True. Yet Matilda we muſt not diſcourage
Our Subjects duties with Ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Then pleaſe me, Sir, in pleaſuring your ſelf,
In the Election of a Worthy Pope.
Ʋictor's demeanouors ſpeak him ſuch.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: We never
Sir heard the contrary.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: I do approve him.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Thanks mighty Prince!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: God ſave Pope Victor the third.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Hildebrand's Name did Anagramatize
His Nature, (I HEL-BRANDD) and ſo he was.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: He was indeed the Worlds Incendiarie.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: A Legion Rebel, (in a wicked Pope)
Muſt be a Complication of Traytors.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: He makes a thouſand hardy-Regicides
With Pardons in their Pockets, and hopes of
Immediate acceſs into Paradiſe:
With a fair promiſe to be Canoniz'd.

sp.speaker: Jun.
sp.l: And then Men run on in their villainies
As eagerly as e're the Pope run from us.
Pox on him! now the warrs are done, and now
We may make Muſtard with our Cannon-bullets,
And ſtick our Swords up to hang Scare-crows on.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.l: Will It pleaſe Caeſar now to grace our Court.

sp.speaker: Emp.
sp.l: Thanks to Your Holyneſs. Come kind Matilda.
Come Gentlemen, you ſhall participate.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: We ſhall attend.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: God ſave Caeſar and Pope Victor!

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 4.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My Revenge cannot ſtay the old mans pace.
I look'd for all the Empire, half, was promiſ'd:
And now he writes, I muſt ſubmiſſively
Yeild to the Portion, of a Younger Brother:
And wait the leiſure of the Deſtinies,
Or never be admitted to his Court.
Souldiers! reſt confident in my Rewards!
And let them highly animate your courage!
I will not make a meal, nor cloſe mine eyes,
Until I'me Emperour of Germany.

div.l: What are you? Come, for Reconciliation?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: I come to tell you, Sir, Your Fathers dead.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: He no ſooner heard your Brothers aime,
(But He reply'd) 'twas time he was Extinguiſh'd,
Finding that ſhort life, he had yet behind
Burnt like a ſnuff, ſo noyſome to his iſſue,
His own Son Henry! And with that, he funck.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Is he quite dead?

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Dead.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Ther's one lett Remov'd.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Brave Conrade, yeild!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: How like a flattering Parret, the Foole talks!
Brave Conrade!

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: 'Tis your Elder Brothers Right.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Pox on't! Can High and Noble Spirits, bent
For a Kingdom, ſtand to tell firſt, and Second?
Fight, Fight! I'le quickly make a younger Brother
Of thee Magnus.

div.stage: They all fight, Conrad's Souldiers are beaten off the Stage, Magnus kills Conrade.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: There was no way but death.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: We have the Conqueſt, Sir, they are quite Routed.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Conveigh this Corps to Solemn Funeral,
We cannot but Lament Bold Conrade's Fall.

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 5.
div.stage: Enter Officers with Brazutus, Jocoſo, and a mixt Company

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: Along, Along!

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.l: What are we apprehended for?

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: The Emperour will tell you.

sp.speaker: 2. Off.
sp.l: Come along.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: So I can, you Hunger-ſtarved-Hound
Without your Haleing.

sp.speaker: 1. Wo.
sp.l: They are very cheats.

sp.speaker: 3. Wo.
sp.l: They mump'd poor Beſſe.

sp.speaker: 2. Wo.
sp.l: Their things w'ant worth a Farthing.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hang 'um, hang 'um they do but gull the Country.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.l: This daies work ſhall coſt you dear.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: 'Tmay coſt your life.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.l: I had a Licenſe from His Royal Father:
Nor will the Princeſs thank you for this rudeneſs.

sp.speaker: 1. Off.
sp.l: W'have order never fear't for what we do.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.l: Y'have ſpoyl'd a Chymiſtrie coſt (God kowes what)

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Y'have brain'd the Gallipots, ye Rogues! the ſtuff
Runs out, ſhall coſt you ſauce, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: 2. Off.
sp.l: Come, come, a Halter will ſoon ſpoil your rayling.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: You may deſerve it firſt.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hang'um quick, Hang'um

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Peace, The Emperour.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Take heed you be'nt in the old womans pickle,
By and by, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Go you Bob-tail'd Whores.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: You whore-ſon Arſe-gut!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Peace the Emperour

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Magnus, I am oblig'd. —

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Sir, here's the Priſ'ner.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Brazutus! you endeavoured to poyſon
Our Royal Father.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.l: Sir, I'me ignorant.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: If you conceal't I ſhall the rather think it.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Perhaps, Matilda might not ſend the Letter,
Pope Gregorie intended for this purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Confeſs all or elſe you dye.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: I n'ere, Sir, murder'd any in my life.

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.l: The old Woman. (I hate lying)

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: I did but faign that, Sir, to get his ſervice.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: How now Brazutus?

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.l: Sir, this is but malice.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: If clear in this yet they may both be faulty.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Declare Brazutus what you're committed,
And on a Princes word, you ſhall have mercy.
(For your ſake Magnus and Aurelia's.)

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.l: If I am guilty, Sir, of this I'me tax'd of,
May I for ever be debarr'd your bounty.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Speak all you know, or ever did, Jocoſo.
If you'r found in a tittle falſ, you dye.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: I never murder'd any but my Mother,
Which Nature had almoſt done to my Hand.
Beſides it was my Elder Brothers doings.
She liv'd ſo long He thought ſhe was Immortal.
His mind was once, to try whether ſhe'd drown:
But I was forc'd at laſt to doe her work
For a mean Fee; I might have ſtarv'd elſe, Sir.
Your mercy, Sir, your mercy!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Horrid Villain!

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: But that your word joyn'd with the Jubilee
Of your firſt Raign, pleads ſomewhat, Sir, for life,
There could be no eſcaping of the Gallows:
However pray think on ſome puniſhment
That may be next to it.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Friends, hear your ſentence.
Brazutus! You Equivocated with us,
More then Jocoſo in your ſlie confeſſion.
(Who poyſon'd a Septinary of Popes!
Both ſhall live in perpetual Priſonment:
look to them Officers, and ſee that daylie
A hard allowance, mind them of their faults.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Sir We obey.
'Tis well yee ſcape ſo

sp.speaker: 2. Off.
sp.l: Come my Friend, Jocoſo.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Pox on your Frendſhip, would we n'ere had met!
How Intimate I muſt be now with Hell!

sp.speaker: Braz.
sp.l: The beſt on't is, old age, ill-uſ'd
Can't ſuffer me, to be Tenant to a Priſon long!

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Magnus! whate're the German Empire now
Rightly deſcended to me, will afford,
Command it freely.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: May Heaven proſper Caeſar!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Look yonder Sylvia.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: I like this well.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Muſt Magnus now be Baniſh'd?

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: Sweet Aurelia!
I can as ſoon be baniſh'd from my ſelf.
(Give me leave Siſter) You will have a man,
Made up of Love, of Juſtice, and of Honour.
I might have call'd theſe Virtues into queſtion,
Had he yeilded to me in hindering
My Fathers Return, to his Empire: which
None but the Fates prevented.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Heaven Bleſs Caeſar!

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Next we muſt Palliate Sophrona's greif.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: That muſt be Magnus in your Nuptials.
Great Duke of Saxony! accept your Dutcheſs,
Accept of your Aurelia!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I flye to Him.

sp.speaker: Syl.
sp.l: Bleſt pair, may yours no more prove April-joyes!

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: We prize things moſt got through a world of Croſſes.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: When thoſe are quite blown over: and now may
You (like the City Alexandria)
Enjoy a conſtant Sun-ſhine ev'ry day!

lg.l: I am to tell you (Gentlemen!) The Play
Caeſar's ſad Tragoedie, you ſaw to day.
Should any Momus crie, it can't be true.
A man Religious, and a Rebel, too.

l.hi: Carp at the Title firſt, and next the Plot,
And then the Sence, the Language, and what not!
Condemn this Poyſon, this Luſt, and that Treaſon,

lg.l: And ſware, our Pilgrim-Prince can't ſtand to reaſon;

l.hi: (But as a Vulgar Errour ſtraight muſt be

lg.l: Our Poet doth confeſs, and 'tis His glory,

l.hi: He plaid the Theif, he ſaith, and ſtole the story
From men of Trust, who write, the thing was ſo,
Acted about Six Hundred years agoe.
But yet all this won't do He understands,
Nothing will paſs for good, without your Hands.
For which great favour, (ſhe who did expreſs
Her ſelf ſo handſome to his Holineſs.)
If ſuch a freindly Girle don't get a clap.
